Chapter.title: Representation and summary of data – measures of dispersion

Question.p: 15 students do a mathematics test. Their marks are shown opposite.
a Find the value of the median.
b Find Q1 and Q3.
c Work out the interquartile range.

Solution.p: Median: 152=7.5 therefore 8th value is needed. Median = 7
b Q1:154=3.75 therefore the 4th value is needed Q1 = 5
Q3:3×154=11.25 therefore the 12th value is needed Q3 = 9

Question.p: A group of workers were asked to write down their weekly wage. The wages were:
a Work out the range for these wages.
b Find Q1 and Q3.
c Work out the interquartile range.

Solution.p: Q1:114=2.75 therefore the 3rd value is needed Q1 = 400
Q3:3×114=8.25 therefore the 9th value is needed Q3 = 505

Question.p: A superstore records the number of hours overtime worked by their employees in one particular week. The results are shown in the table.
a Fill in the cumulative frequency column and work out how many employees the superstore had in that week.
b Find Q1 and Q3.
c Work out the interquartile range.

Solution.p: b Q1:1004=25 therefore the average of the 25th and 26th values is Q1 = 0.5
Q3:3×1004=75 therefore the average of the 75th and 76th values is Q3 = 4

Question.p: A moth trap was set every night for five weeks. The number of moths caught in the trap was recorded. The results are shown in the table.
Find the interquartile range.

Solution.p: Q1:354=8.75 therefore the 9th value is needed Q1 = 9
Q3:3×354=26.25 therefore the 27th value is needed Q3 = 10

Question.p: The weights of 31 Jersey cows were recorded to the nearest kilogram. The weights are shown in the table.
a Complete the cumulative frequency column in the table.
b Find the lower quartile, Q1.
c Find the upper quartile, Q3.
d Find the interquartile range.

Solution.p: Q1:314=7.75th value so Q1 is in class 350 − 399
c Q3:3×314=23.25th value so Q3 is in class 450 − 499

Question.p: The number of visitors to a hospital in a week was recorded. The results are shown in the table.
Giving your answers to the nearest whole number find:
a the lower quartile Q1, b the upper quartile Q3, c the interquartile range.

Solution.p: Q1:604=15th value so Q1 is in class 1000 − 1500
b Q3:3×604=45th value so Q3 is in class 1500 − 2000

Question.p: The lengths of a number of slow worms were measured, to the nearest mm. The results are shown in the table.
a Work out how many slow worms were measured.
b Find the interquartile range for the lengths of the slow worms.

Solution.p: b Q1:714=17.75th value so Q1 is in class 185 − 199
Q3:3×714=53.25th value so Q3 is in class 200−214

Question.p: A gardener counted the peas in a number of pea pods. The results are shown in the table.
a Complete the cumulative frequency column.
b Calculate the 80th percentile.
c Calculate the 40th percentile
d Calculate the 65th percentile.
A shopkeeper goes to a clothes fair. He records the costs of jeans. The costs are shown in the table.
a Complete the cumulative frequency table.
b Calculate P20.
c Calculate P80.
d Calculate the 20% to 80% interpercentile range.
The table shows the monthly income for a number of workers in a factory.
Calculate the 34% to 66% interpercentile range.
A train travelled from Lancaster to Preston. The times, to the nearest minute, it took for the journey were recorded over a certain period. The times are shown in the table.
Calculate the 5% to 95% interpercentile range.

A roadside assistance firm kept a record over a week of the amount of time, in minutes, people were kept waiting for assistance in a particular part of the country. The time taken was from the time the phone call was received to the arrival of the breakdown mechanic. The times are shown below.
a Work out the number of people who called for assistance.
b Calculate the 30th percentile.
c Calculate the 65th percentile.
Given that for a variable x:
Find:
a The mean. b The variance σ2. c The standard deviation σ.
Ten collie dogs are weighed (w kg). The following summary data for the weights are shown below:
Use this summary data to find the standard deviation of the collies’ weights.
Eight students’ heights (h cm) are measured. They are as follows:
a Work out the mean height of the students.
b Given Σh2 = 254 307 work out the variance. Show all your working.
c Work out the standard deviation.
For a set of 10 numbers:
For a set of 15 numbers:
Find the mean and the standard deviation of the combined set of 25 numbers.
The number of members (m) in six scout groups was recorded. The summary statistics for these data are:
a Work out the mean number of members in a scout group.
b Work out the standard deviation of the number of members in the scout groups.

There are two routes for a worker to get to his office. Both the routes involve hold ups due to traffic lights. He records the time it takes over a series of six journeys for each route. The results are shown in the table.
a Work out the mean time taken for each route.
b Calculate the variance and the standard deviation of each of the two routes.
c Using your answers to a and b suggest which route you would recommend. State your reason clearly.

Solution.p: c Route 1 as although the means are the same the standard deviation is less meaning the times are more consistent and the journey is less likely to take longer than expected.

Question.p: For a certain set of data:
Work out the variance for these data.
For a certain set of data
Work out the standard deviation for these data.
Nahab asks the students in his year group how much pocket money they get per week. The results, rounded to the nearest pound, are shown in the table.
a Complete the table.
b Using the formula Σfx2Σf−(ΣfxΣf)2 work out the variance for these data.
c Work out the standard deviation for these data.
In a student group, a record was kept of the number of days absence each student had over one particular term. The results are shown in the table.
a Complete the table.
b Calculate the variance for these data.
c Work out the standard deviation for these data.
A certain type of machine contained a part that tended to wear out after different amounts of time. The time it took for 50 of the parts to wear out was recorded. The results are shown in the table.
a Complete the table.
b Calculate an estimate for the variance and the standard deviation for these data.
The heights (x cm) of a group of 100 women were recorded.
The summary data is as follows:
Work out the variance and the standard deviation.
a Work out the standard deviation of the following data.
b Use the following coding to find the standard deviation of the data. Show all the working.
i x − 10 iix10 iiix−32
Use the following codings to find the standard deviation of the following weights, w.
ii w − 200
a The coding y=x−5028 gives a standard deviation of 0.01 for y. Work out the standard deviation for x.
b The coding y=h15 produced a standard deviation for y of 0.045. What is the standard deviation of h?
c The coding y = x − 14 produced a standard deviation for y of 2.37. What is the standard deviation of x?
d The coding y=s−510 produced a standard deviation for y of 0.65. What is the standard deviation of s?
The coding y = x − 40 gives a standard deviation for y of 2.34. Write down the standard deviation of x.
The lifetime, x, in hours, of 70 light bulbs is shown in the table.
Using the coding y=x−120 estimate the standard deviation of the actual lifetime in hours of a light bulb.
The weekly income, i, of 100 women workers was recorded.
The data were coded using y=i−90100 and the following summations were obtained.
Work out an estimate for the standard deviation of the actual women workers’ weekly income.
A meteorologist collected data on the annual rainfall, x mm, at six randomly selected places. The data were coded using s = 0.01x − 10 and the following summations were obtained.
Work out an estimate for the standard deviation of the actual annual rainfall.
For the set of numbers:
a work out the median,
b work out the lower quartile,
c work out the upper quartile,
d work out the interquartile range.
A frequency distribution is shown below
Work out the interquartile range.

Solution.p: Q1:504=12.5th value so Q1 is in class 21 – 40
Q3:3×504=37.5th value so Q3 is in class 61 – 80

Question.p: A frequency distribution is shown below.
a Work out the value of the 30th percentile.
b Work out the value of the 70th percentile.
c Calculate the 30% to 70% interpercentile range.
The heights (h) of 10 mountains were recorded to the nearest 10 m and are shown in the table below.
Use the coding y=h−100010 to find the standard deviation of the heights.
The times it took a random sample of runners to complete a race are summarised in the table.
a Work out the lower quartile.
b Work out the upper quartile.
c Work out the interquartile range.
The mid-point of each class was represented by x and its corresponding frequency by f giving:
d Estimate the variance and standard deviation for these data.

Solution.p: a Data is continuous so: Q1:804=20th value so Q1 is in class 40 – 49
b Q3:3×804=60th value so Q3 is in class 50 – 59

Question.p: 20 birds were caught for ringing.
Their wing spans (x) were measured to the nearest centimetre.
The following summary data was worked out:
a Work out the mean and the standard deviation of the wing spans of the 20 birds. One more bird was caught. It had a wing span of 13 centimetres
b Without doing any further working say how you think this extra wing span will affect the mean wing span.

Solution.p: b It will decrease the mean wing span since 13 < 15.8

Question.p: The heights of 50 clover flowers are summarised in the table.
a Find Q1.
b Find Q2.
c Find the interquartile range.
d Use Σfx = 5075 and Σfx2 = 516 112.5 to find the standard deviation.

Solution.p: Q1:504=12.5th value so Q1 is in class 95 – 100
b Q3:3×504=37.5th value so Q3 is in class 100 – 105
